Patch Set 27:

(5 comments)
this is more like configSdrSensor() to me.
Ack
Done
pass by value here
Ack
Done
I don't understand how can this variable auto increment within this loop. This is a physical ipmb bus index, right? Please explain why it would increment as iteration at line 539.

yes, it is a physical IPMB bus. For sensorRecord map, ipmbBusIndex value is declared as key. Also, ipmbBusIndex value will be assigned to 0 as default, if it is not present in config for IpmbSensor.

Since one of the bus value is 0 for SDR, I have incremented with 1, so that the keys in the map will be different for IpmbSensor and SDR sensor.
Logic is simplified by creating if condition for SDR sensor. IpmbSensor code remains unchanged.

Done

Logic is simplified by creating if condition for SDR sensor.
Done
Why not only create SDRDevice record for busIndex that has sdrInterface

Since the object creating is same for both IpmbSensor and SDRSensor, I have created device record for IpmbSensor also. If these two objects can be created separately, then it can be avoided.

Could you please provide your suggestion on creating two objects for sensor?

After reading through the code couple times, I think I understand your logic here now. But I think using this "fake" entry in the sensorRecord and offset of ipmbBusIndex is hard to understand and maintain. 
Plus, I am not sure line625-629 is needed for the SDRSensor type.

It would be better to keep the logic simple:
1. SDR config, create SDR sensor based on the map
2. IpmbSensor config, keep the code unchanged

Additional question:
How are these SDRSensor value being updated? Does the read function and periodic polling from IpmbSesnor base class work for these sensor?

I have created separate if condition for SDR sensor and IpmbSensor code is unchanged.

Read function and polling works based on the IpmbSensor base class. Same IpmbSensor constructor is used for SDR sensor to update the sensor value.
nit: sensorType?
This array is based on IPMI spec sensor unit type codes. There is another reference for sensorType table. Therefore, to differentiate those tables, I named this variable as sensorUnits.

related to question for patch
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/52160/21/src/IpmbSensor.cpp#615
implies that there is an object of IpmbSDRDevice for one ipmbBus. 

It would be a cleaner design if each IpmbSDRDevice holds sensorRecord for its own bus.

Could you please clarify your suggestion.

Like sensorRecord, need to create multiple variable for each IPMB device ?
Ack
please add comment on why this is done.
Done
Any rational behind this magic number?
No, this is to wait until all the sensors are retrieved from IPMB Device.
Where is this global flag unset? I assume intend is to have createSensors (line686) run with ipmbSDREnable = true. createS4ensors at Line760 should run with ipmbSDREnable = false

yes, in default it will be set as false, if SDR is present, then it will be true before calling create sensors function.

If both IpmbSensor and SDRSensor interface is created, then SDR sensor will not have all sensor information at first, therefore, this flag can be used to ensure when the sensor information is complete. IpmbSensor can be read by ignoring SDR sensor when line760 called.
My question is once it is set once, it stays set. That does not seem right.
It is passed as an argument to createSensors function, therefore, whenever IpmbSensor type is present, the flag will be false.
You are right. I see how it is working now. I somehow was looking at an older version where the flag was a global variable.
magic number
This timer is to wait until all the sensors are retrieved from IPMB Device.
Instead of passing everything to lambda, only pass those arguments which are required. .
Done

rt now code ll create sensor at line 636 even if interface is not an sdr interface.

Is this expected behavior? or should this function return false and the handle error from where it is called?
In line 619, sdr interface condition is checked before calling this function.
So this check and parameter interface can be removed.
if we are not gonna init the sensor should the obj be still kept? or sensor obj should be removed?
I think there is no need to remove the object, since it will handle automatically.
Can some or all of these be skipped if intf == adrInterface?
not needed for sdr sensors, thresholds will be in sensorInfo, right?
These lines are duplication for line650 - 663. Refactor it out into a function to avoid duplication
This is incorrect, sensors includes non sdr sensor.
